Not your taste? Try something else from The Pudding.
Tens of millions of people are curious about how to properly dice an onion, according to YouTube.
In 2021, renowned Chef / food journalist J. Kenji López-Alt broke out some math to optimize a technique for getting uniform piece sizes.

It matters* far more for winning internet debates and solving interesting math problems than it does for cooking. For home cooks, having an onion dice that's a little off from perfect is not really an issue anyone should seriously worry about.

hed: The Mathematically Optimal Way to Dice an Onion

story.value: This is an onion. It is also a series of concentric circles. What’s the best way to cut it? That is, how do we get the most uniform piece size?
Let’s try a common approach - <mark>all vertical cuts</mark>.
The pieces near the center line are fairly consistent in shape and size.
But along the bottom there are some noticeably larger pieces. When you dice an onion, you are probably not imaging pieces like these.
This inconsistency can be measured by calculating the standard deviation. A higher value means a greater variation in piece size.
Adjust the slider to see how the standard deviation changes with the number of cuts.
Okay, let’s try a different technique - <mark>radial cuts</mark>.
The piece size still isn’t very consistent - those near the outside are much larger than those near the center.
How does the standard deviation of pieces cut radially compare to those cut vertically?
But we can improve the radial cut strategy. Kenji claims that the most uniform pieces can be produced by aiming at a point ~60% of the onion’s radius below the cutting surface.
The pieces now look more consistent, except for a few smaller ones along the bottom.
